**Chapter 7**

The tallow candle burned with a steady, quiet flame, a single point of order in the oppressive dark of the substation. It cast long, dancing shadows of the dead transformers, making them seem like silent, colossal mourners at a wake for a forgotten age of power. In the small pool of light, the bright, waxy red of the lipstick stood out in shocking contrast to the deep, flaking umber of the rusted sheet metal. As Kaelen spoke, their voice a low, steady murmur, Fenwick’s hand moved with the meticulous precision he usually reserved for arranging a new display of sea glass. He was no artist, but he was a master of lines, categories, and spatial relationships. The lipstick, a tool of human vanity, became a cartographer’s pen, laying down a geography of despair.

Kaelen’s memory was a Sorter’s memory: sharp, categorized, and ruthlessly efficient. They did not speak of winding tunnels, but of ‘Class-4 drainage conduits’ and ‘decommissioned pneumatic tube lines.’ They described junctions not by their appearance, but by their acoustic properties and the mineral content of their water seepage. Fenwick translated this stream of raw data into a schematic of breathtaking complexity. He drew the main arteries of the under-city as thick, confident lines, the lesser capillaries as delicate cross-hatching. He marked compromised zones with a jagged ‘X’, known Corruptor patrols with a series of dots, and safe pockets of stillness with a simple, reassuring circle. It was a testament to his craft that the emerging diagram was not a chaotic scrawl but a thing of stark, functional beauty—a map of a broken world, but a map nonetheless. Order, wrested from chaos, one lipstick line at a time.

“Here,” Kaelen said, their thin finger tapping a spot on the metal sheet, smudging the rust but leaving the waxy red line intact. “This is the old Industrial Sector. Abandoned by the Over-Worlders a generation ago when their manufactories failed. It’s a graveyard of iron and ambition.” Their finger traced a path to a large, complex shape that Fenwick had just finished outlining. “The heart of the sector was the old Dominion Ironworks. A foundry. A place of creation, where they took raw ore and rock and, with fire and force, gave it purpose. A blast furnace, casting floors, rail lines to bring in coal and take out finished steel.” Kaelen’s voice grew grim. “The Corruptors appreciate the irony. They have made it their Un-foundry. They have taken a place of making and turned it into a sanctuary of breaking.”

Fenwick studied the lipstick diagram, his mind sorting the tactical implications. The Un-foundry was not an isolated structure; it was the nexus of a web of old utility corridors, ore-cart tunnels, and ventilation shafts. A fortress, but a porous one. "Their main entrance will be guarded," he murmured, thinking aloud. "And the direct routes will be patrolled."

"More than guarded," Kaelen confirmed, shaking their head. "The approaches are seeded. Not just with patrols, but with their works. False floors over pits of industrial sludge. Support beams weakened to collapse at the slightest vibration. Tunnels where they've rerouted gas lines, just waiting for a spark. They have turned the entire district into a single, massive trap. To try a direct approach is to walk into the jaws of a machine designed to chew you up and spit you out as unsorted waste." The image was so viscerally horrifying that Fenwick felt a fresh wave of nausea. This was a war of philosophy, being fought with rebar and broken concrete.

Fenwick looked at Kaelen, seeing the deep exhaustion etched on their face, but also the flicker of a resilient, analytical mind. "But a system, even a system of chaos, has rules," Fenwick stated. "It has inputs and outputs. They bring in salvage to corrupt. They send out Seeds of Decay. How?" Kaelen’s eyes lit up, recognizing the line of inquiry. "The old rail lines. There's a single, semi-functional ore-cart line they use for heavy transport. It runs from a collection point near the scrapyards, directly into the foundry's processing core."

"Then that's an entry point," Fenwick said, but Kaelen was already shaking their head. "It's a bottleneck. They watch it day and night. Any cart that moves along that line is accounted for. It's a conveyor belt into their furnace." Fenwick’s gaze drifted over the map, his mind moving past the obvious paths. He looked at the negative space, the areas Kaelen hadn't marked as conduits or tunnels. His finger, smudged with red wax, came to rest on a small, insignificant-looking symbol connected to the main foundry diagram. "What is this? The symbol for an air duct?"

Kaelen leaned closer, squinting. "The old main furnace ventilator. Decommissioned. It vents to a smokestack on the surface, half a mile away. It's blocked, collapsed in three places according to the old city schematics. Useless." Fenwick tapped the symbol again, a thrill of counter-intuitive logic running through him. "The Corruptors value function, even if it's the function of destruction. They are pragmatists in their own twisted way. They would see a collapsed tunnel as a worthless liability. They wouldn't guard it. They wouldn't even think about it." He looked at Kaelen. "But a collapse is just a pile of unsorted material. It's not an absolute barrier. It's a sorting problem." A slow smile spread across Kaelen’s grimy face. "You want to try and dig your way through a collapsed ventilation shaft that hasn't been used in fifty years?" "It's the path they won't expect," Fenwick replied simply. "It's the flaw in their chaotic design."

The plan solidified. They would rest, re-equip, and then make for the surface outlet of the ventilation shaft. It was a desperate, laborious strategy, but it was a Sorter's strategy, predicated on patience and the belief that any pile of rubble could be categorized, moved, and ultimately, overcome. After Kaelen had consumed more jerky and clean water, a little strength returned to their limbs. They began to prepare. Kaelen’s hidden burrow was sparse, but every item was a masterpiece of purpose. From a hidden recess, they produced a coil of thin, incredibly strong wire salvaged from a high-tension cable, and a set of delicate metal probes of varying shapes and sizes. "Lockpicks?" Fenwick asked, impressed. "System interface tools," Kaelen corrected. "For persuading reluctant mechanisms." Fenwick, in turn, offered his remaining chalk and the lump of charcoal for marking their path. It was a meager arsenal, but it was theirs. As they were packing, Fenwick’s hand brushed against the small, tarnished silver locket in his pouch. An idea, born of his peculiar expertise, sparked in his mind. "Kaelen," he said, holding up the locket. "Do you have anything that reflects light? A piece of polished tin? A mirror shard?"

Kaelen rummaged in a small crate and produced a fragment of a truck's wing mirror, its edges sharp and dangerous. "What for?" Fenwick took the mirror shard. "The Corruptors operate in the dark, but their Un-foundry is a place of fire and light. A periscope. For seeing around corners without being seen." He then opened the silver locket. Using one of Kaelen's finer probes, he carefully worked the two halves of the locket apart at the hinge. He now had two small, cup-like pieces of silver. "And a signaling device," he explained, holding one of the concave pieces up to the candlelight, which gathered the faint light into a single, brighter point. "To communicate silently over distances." Kaelen watched, a look of profound respect on their face. "You repurposed a piece of sentimental jewellery into two distinct tactical tools. You, Fenwick Mossbottom, are a very strange and useful kind of Sorter." Fenwick merely grunted, a soft sound of satisfaction, as he carefully packed the pieces away. He had lost his tongs, but he was beginning to realize that his most valuable tool was his own mind. Fully equipped and with a map seared into their minds, they extinguished the candle, plunging the substation back into darkness. They slipped out of the maintenance panel and back into the cold, silent tunnels, leaving the small sanctuary behind. They were no longer fleeing. They were hunting.

The journey to the old Industrial Sector was a pilgrimage through forgotten histories. Kaelen led them through a network of passages that existed on no official schematic, a secret anatomy known only to the deep-dwellers. These were not the grand, echoing sewers, but tight, dusty service corridors and the hollow bones of long-dead pneumatic tube systems. The air was still and thick, tasting of powdered concrete and the faint, metallic ghost of rust. They moved in a bubble of silence, their soft footfalls absorbed by the thick carpet of dust. Fenwick, following close behind his new companion, found his Sorter's mind automatically cataloguing the strata of decay: the layer of fine grey dust from the age of concrete construction, overlaid with the coarser, reddish dust of iron oxidation, and topped with the modern, greasy soot that had filtered down from the world above. It was a geology of neglect.

Their silent progress was punctuated by stark, disturbing reminders of their enemy. At one junction of crisscrossing pipes, Kaelen paused, holding up a hand. They pointed to a thick iron support pillar holding up a ceiling of crumbling brickwork. At its base, where the pillar was bolted to the floor, the massive nuts were not merely loose; they were grotesquely swollen, their threads split as if they had been designed to corrode and expand from within, exerting a slow, inexorable pressure that had cracked the concrete around them. It was a Seed of Decay on an architectural scale, a load-bearing column patiently being taught to fail. Fenwick stared at the sabotage, a cold knot tightening in his stomach. The Corruptors did not just break things; they inverted their very purpose. A bolt, meant to hold things together, was now an agent of their eventual, violent separation. It was an act of profound ontological violence that struck him more deeply than any simple act of destruction.

After what seemed like hours of navigating the silent labyrinth, the quality of the air began to change. The dead stillness was replaced by a faint, almost imperceptible draft, and with it came new scents. The clean, cold smell of rain-washed metal, the acrid tang of chemical pollutants, and the damp, earthy aroma of weeds growing in cracked concrete. They were nearing the surface. Kaelen led them to the base of a tall, narrow shaft where a rusted iron ladder ascended into a patch of slightly less-than-total darkness. As they climbed, the sounds of the deep tunnels faded, replaced by the mournful sigh of wind whistling through broken structures. They emerged not into the open air, but into the cavernous ruin of a ground-floor workshop. Skeletal machines, shrouded in dust and cobwebs, stood like silent, patient beasts. Through a series of shattered windows, Fenwick got his first proper look at the Dominion Ironworks. It was a cathedral of rust, a sprawling complex of skeletal gantries, silent conveyor belts, and colossal, crumbling smokestacks that clawed at the bruised grey sky like the fingers of a buried giant. This was a place that had once been the very definition of creation, a testament to the goblin-adjacent ideal of taking raw, chaotic matter and forging it into something of strength and purpose. Now it was a monument to its own failure, a perfect breeding ground for the Unmaker's philosophy.

Using the lipstick-smeared map as their guide, they skirted the edges of the ruined compound, moving from the shadow of one crumbling brick wall to the next. The ground was a treacherous landscape of twisted rebar, shattered glass, and deep, rust-coloured puddles. The sheer scale of the dereliction was overwhelming, a testament to the heedless way the Over-Worlders abandoned their own creations. Fenwick felt a pang of what was almost pity for the place itself, a vast, complex organism left to die. Kaelen, ever the pragmatist, was focused solely on their goal, their sharp eyes scanning the skyline, matching the pattern of smokestacks to the diagram on the rust-sheet. They finally located their target: a shorter, thicker smokestack set apart from the main cluster, its brickwork stained a darker shade of grime. Following its base, they found where it connected to the main foundry building, and there, half-buried in a landslide of rubble and debris from a collapsed roof, was a large, circular vent covered by a heavy iron grille. It was the ventilator shaft, as forgotten and impassable as they had hoped.

Prying the grille loose required their combined strength and one of Kaelen's sturdier probes used as a lever. It came away with a groan of protesting metal and a shower of rust, revealing a dark, circular maw that exhaled a puff of air so stale it felt ancient. The shaft was just wide enough for them to walk in a stooped position. They lit the tallow candle, its small flame flickering wildly in the sudden draft, and entered, pulling the grille back into place behind them. The beam of light revealed a tunnel lined with smooth, riveted metal, sloping gently downwards into the earth. The silence in here was different—it was the pressed, sealed silence of a tomb. They had not travelled more than a hundred feet when their path was blocked. A section of the ceiling had given way, filling the shaft from floor to roof with a dense, interlocking mass of broken concrete, twisted pipes, and compacted earth. It looked utterly solid, a concrete plug a dozen feet thick. Kaelen aimed a kick at a protruding chunk of rubble, which didn't budge. "This isn't a collapse," they muttered in frustration. "It's a new wall."

Fenwick, however, did not see a wall. He saw an acquisition. He approached the blockage slowly, holding the candle high, his eyes scanning the chaotic surface with the intensity of a gem-cutter studying a raw stone. His gaze flickered from piece to piece, not seeing them as individual obstacles but as components in a single, complex structure. He noted the way a large, flat slab of concrete was wedged against a bent I-beam, which in turn was supported by a tangle of smaller pipes. He saw how the pressure flowed through the mass, how certain pieces were under immense compression while others were merely fill. This wasn't a solid mass; it was a puzzle, a three-dimensional jigsaw of stress and balance. He had spent his life sorting objects by material, by colour, by provenance. Now he was sorting by function, by load, by the role each piece played in this accidental, chaotic architecture.

"This is not a problem for force," Fenwick said, his voice quiet with concentration. "It is a problem of categorization. We dig here," he said, pointing with a grimy finger to a collection of smaller bricks and loose earth packed under the main I-beam. "This is non-structural fill. If we remove it, we relieve the upward pressure on the beam. Then," he traced a line in the air with his finger, "we can slide this length of pipe out sideways, which will allow that large slab to settle downwards by a few inches, opening a gap near the top." Kaelen stared, first at the solid wall of rubble, then at Fenwick's calm, analytical face. They had seen Fenwick as a strange but useful collector, a theorist. Now, for the first time, they saw the raw, practical power of his philosophy in action. He wasn't just planning to dig; he was planning to deconstruct, to Unsort the collapse itself. Kaelen nodded slowly, a new kind of hope dawning in their eyes. They took out their smallest, sharpest probe, ready to use it as a chisel. The work of Order, in its most literal, physical form, was about to begin.

**Chapter 8**

The work was a slow, painstaking surgery on a body of stone and steel. In the flickering, insufficient light of the single candle, the wall of rubble was a complex tapestry of shadows and textures. Kaelen, wielding their sharpest probe like a scalpel, chipped away at the crumbling mortar and loose soil that Fenwick indicated, their movements economical and precise. Fenwick worked with his bare hands, his long fingers, so accustomed to the delicate work of sorting bottle caps and buttons, proving equally adept at discerning the subtle shifts in pressure and weight within the chaotic mass. He would feel for a loose brick, test its role in the structure, and if he deemed it non-essential, he would carefully work it free, passing it back to Kaelen who would add it to a neat, growing pile behind them. It was a reversal of a collapse, a deliberate and meticulous act of un-falling. The air grew thick with a fine powder of ancient concrete and dried earth, a dust that caked their faces and rasped in their throats, but they worked on, a two-goblin engine of focused deconstruction.

Their collaboration was a silent symphony of shared purpose. Fenwick was the eye, his mind constructing and deconstructing the puzzle of the blockage, seeing the lines of force and the points of weakness. Kaelen was the hand, their practical skill and wiry strength translating Fenwick’s abstract analysis into physical action. When a stubborn length of pipe, wedged deep in the mass, refused to budge, Fenwick would indicate the precise point of leverage, and Kaelen, using their rebar-like probe, would apply pressure with a practiced grunt until the pipe groaned and shifted. There was no need for words. A pointed finger, a questioning glance, a nod of confirmation—this was the language of two Sorters engaged in the purest form of their craft, imposing order on a universe of senseless junk, one piece at a time. The neat pile of extracted material grew behind them, sorted instinctively by size and material, a small island of principle in a sea of chaos.

As Kaelen worked to free a large, triangular chunk of concrete, Fenwick’s questing fingers brushed against something that was not stone or rusted metal. It was smooth, cool, and curved. His curiosity overriding the urgency of their task for a moment, he began to carefully excavate around the object. Kaelen paused their work, giving him an impatient look, but Fenwick was already lost in the small act of discovery. He unearthed a metal box, its surface dented and its original blue paint almost entirely obscured by a half-century of rust. An Over-Worlder’s lunchbox. Its clasp was rusted shut, a small puzzle in itself. Using the tip of a fine probe from Kaelen's kit, Fenwick patiently worked at the mechanism, scraping away the corrosion until, with a final, protesting squeak, the lid popped open. Inside, perfectly preserved in the dry, stagnant air, lay the fossil of a forgotten moment: the petrified, dark brown core of an apple, a single folded sheet of yellowed newspaper, and a small, hand-carved wooden bird, its form simple but full of life. It was the residue of a life, a story packed away and forgotten. Fenwick felt a pang of profound connection to the unknown ironworker who had sat in this tunnel fifty years ago to eat his lunch. This, he thought, was the antithesis of the Unmaker’s creed. This was a story, not of failure, but of quiet existence, of making, of a small, personal order.

The discovery lent a new gravity to their work. They were not just clearing a path; they were archaeologists of a lost world, honouring its memory with their careful labour. Their focus renewed, they returned to the main problem. The final piece of the puzzle was the great I-beam, the linchpin holding the entire upper section of the collapse in place. With all the supporting fill beneath it removed, it now rested precariously on a jutting edge of concrete. Following Fenwick's gestured instructions, they both found purchase and pushed. The beam resisted, groaning a low, deep note of protest that vibrated through the tunnel. They pushed harder, their muscles straining, and with a sudden, terrifying crack, the beam shifted. It slid sideways, scraping a shower of sparks from the concrete, and the entire mass of rubble above it dropped a full two feet with a deafening roar and a great, choking billow of dust that instantly snuffed out their candle. They were plunged into roaring, blind panic, the sound of a ton of settling rubble echoing all around them.

When the last pebble had skittered to a halt, a profound silence fell. Kaelen, their hands shaking slightly, managed to strike another match. The flame bloomed, unsteady at first, then held. In its light, they saw that Fenwick's calculations had been perfect. The chaos had resolved itself. The main slab of concrete had not fallen completely but had settled onto the displaced I-beam, and in the space where the top of the rubble had been, a narrow, triangular gap had opened. It was dark and forbidding, barely wide enough for a goblin to squeeze through, but it was a path. A wave of triumphant relief washed over Fenwick, so potent it almost buckled his knees. He had looked at a mountain and had sorted it into a molehill. He had met chaos with its opposite, and chaos had yielded.

Kaelen, wasting no time on celebration, handed their pack to Fenwick and wriggled through the opening first, their lean form disappearing into the blackness. Fenwick pushed his own sack through, then followed, scraping his already bruised shoulder on the rough edges of the concrete. He emerged on the other side into another section of the ventilation shaft. This side was clear of debris, a long, dark tube of riveted metal stretching downwards into blackness. But the air here was completely different. It was not the dead, stale air of the collapsed section; it was alive, and it was hot. It tasted of hot oil, ozone, and something else, a bitter, chemical smell of burning plastics that was sickeningly familiar. The silence was gone, too. From the depths of the shaft below, a sound began to reach them, a sound that grew from a faint vibration in the metal floor to a deep, rhythmic, all-pervading thunder. It was the sound of a colossal hammer striking an anvil, a sound of relentless, industrial violence. *CLANG… CRUNCH… CLANG… CRUNCH.* Far down the sloping tunnel, a dim, pulsing light painted the darkness, a hellish orange glow that waxed and waned in time with the hammer blows. They had made it. They were inside the perimeter. They were standing at the threshold of the Un-foundry, looking down its throat, and it was roaring.

**Chapter 9**

The ventilation shaft was a throat, and it was swallowing them whole. They descended the long, sloping tube not by walking, but in a controlled, skittering slide, the hot metal vibrating under their feet with every rhythmic, seismic blow from the Un-foundry’s heart. The air was a physical assault, thick with the fumes of burnt insulation and vaporized oil, and so hot that it felt as if it was being inhaled directly from an oven. The pulsing orange glow from below was no longer a dim suggestion of light but a lurid, throbbing aurora that painted the riveted walls in shades of fire and rust. The sound was the world. It was a physical pressure on Fenwick’s ears and chest, a monstrous industrial heartbeat that sought to overwhelm thought and replace it with its own brutal, two-beat cadence: *CLANG…* a moment of screaming metal, then *CRUNCH…* a sickening finality, followed by a brief, hissing silence before the cycle began anew.

They slid to a halt on a small, grated service platform where the main shaft met a smaller, horizontal duct. This was their designated observation point, a small balcony overlooking the abyss. The noise here was a deafening, soul-shaking roar, and the heat washed over them in waves. To peek over the edge was to invite immediate discovery. This was the moment Fenwick had prepared for. With hands that trembled slightly, not from fear but from a strange, reverent excitement at the application of a theory, he retrieved the shard of wing mirror and one half of the repurposed silver locket. He showed Kaelen how to hold the mirror shard through the grate at a precise angle while he, positioned further back in the darkness of the side-duct, used the concave silver to catch the reflected image. It was a crude, jury-rigged periscope, a device of pure order and cleverness in a place dedicated to its opposite.

The image that swam into view on the curved, polished silver was a vision from a Sorter’s most profound nightmare. They were looking down into a vast, vaulted cavern, the original casting floor of the old ironworks, now transformed into a hellscape of perverted industry. In the center, directly beneath the hammer, was the source of the noise: a colossal, steam-belching machine, a monstrous hybrid of a rock crusher and a hydraulic press. Fenwick watched in silent, spiritual agony as a conveyor belt fed a stream of pristine salvage into its maw—gleaming copper pipes, neatly bundled aluminum siding, perfectly functional gears and engine blocks. The great hammer, a solid block of pitted iron the size of a small cottage, would rise, pause, and then fall with that cataclysmic *CLANG*, crushing the perfectly good material into a tangled, composite mass of wreckage. The second part of the cycle, the *CRUNCH*, was the sound of powerful hydraulic rams compressing the wreckage into a dense, unsortable bale of mixed, ruined metals, which was then spat out onto a growing mountain of irredeemable junk. It was not a machine of destruction; it was a machine of anti-creation, its sole purpose to take things of value and render them into a state of permanent, unrecoverable chaos.

Fenwick felt a horror so deep and pure it was almost a religious experience. This was blasphemy on an industrial scale. Every fiber of his being, every principle he had ever held, recoiled from the sight. He had spent his life believing in the inherent spirit of every object, its potential to be useful again. That machine was a god-killer, murdering the souls of things for no other reason than to watch them die. It was the Unmaker’s high altar, and this was its sacrament of filth. He saw Corruptors, their faces illuminated by the orange glow, moving with a grim, focused purpose that was a sickening parody of a Sorter’s diligence. They were not cackling maniacs; they were technicians, workers on a production line of decay.

He passed the locket-half to Kaelen, whose reaction was immediate and starkly different. Where Fenwick saw philosophical horror, Kaelen saw a tactical problem. “The Un-maker’s Anvil,” Kaelen breathed, their eyes narrowed in concentration as they studied the reflected image. “It runs on steam, see the boiler pipes? The main press is hydraulic. They’re feeding it the best salvage first. It’s not just destruction; it’s a calculated removal of high-value reusable materials from the entire scrap-cycle.” Their gaze shifted. “Look. The finishing stations.” They angled the mirror, and Fenwick looked again. Along the edges of the cavern, other Corruptors were at work at crude benches. One was taking brand-new screws and systematically stripping their heads with a powered grinder. Another was dipping shiny, perfect ball bearings into a vat of bubbling green acid before packing them into grease-paper. A third was carefully painting a clear, corrosive lacquer onto the contacts of salvaged circuit boards. They were taking order and meticulously, painstakingly, injecting it with failure.

The sheer, diabolical ingenuity of it all stole Fenwick’s breath. This was a war being fought on a level he had never conceived of, a war against the future, against the very possibility of repair. "We can't stop that," Fenwick stated, the words tasting like ash in his mouth. "That machine… it's too big. We are two goblins with a piece of wire and a mirror." "No," Kaelen agreed, their eyes still scanning the horrific panorama. "We can't destroy the Anvil. Not today. But an operation this size requires logistics. It requires its own kind of order." Their gaze settled on a small, elevated brick structure built against the far wall of the cavern, its windows dark but with a single, steady light burning within. A rickety wooden staircase led up to its door. "The foreman's office. The dispatch hub. All their work orders, their shipping manifests, their formulas for corrosion… their data will be in there."

The objective snapped into focus, clear and hard as diamond. They couldn’t destroy the Un-foundry, but they could blind it. They could steal its memory, its schedule, its profane knowledge. To steal the Unmaker’s logbooks would be a wound far deeper than smashing a few tools. It would be a Sorter’s victory, a triumph of information over entropy. A plan began to form, a desperate path traced across the reflected image in the locket. A maintenance ladder led down from a platform not far from their shaft. It descended to the foundry floor behind a colossal, dormant boiler. From there, a network of overhead pipes and gantries provided a treacherous, elevated highway that crossed the main floor, passing almost directly over the fuming mountain of crushed scrap. It was a path that led to the base of the stairs to the foreman’s office.

Kaelen pointed with a trembling finger. "There. That's our route." Fenwick studied the path, his mind automatically sorting the risks. The ladder was exposed. The gantries were high and narrow. And worse, at the base of the ladder, half-hidden in the steam and shadow, was a lounging Corruptor, a guard ostensibly watching the boiler but whose gaze swept lazily across the foundry floor. The path was there, a thin, shimmering thread of possibility woven through a tapestry of certain death. They had found their way in. Now they had to risk it all and go down into the roaring heart of the chaos itself.

Kaelen lowered the mirror shard, the reflected inferno vanishing as the small piece of silver in Fenwick’s hand went dark. “One guard. The path is clear otherwise. A direct confrontation is... inefficient.” The word hung in the air, a goblin understatement for 'suicidal.' Fenwick, however, was not looking at the path. His eyes, guided by a lifetime of scanning for the overlooked, had found something else in the reflected image. It was a detail Kaelen, the systems expert, had missed: a length of discarded copper tubing, bent into a U-shape, lying on a metal shelf just inside their ventilation shaft. It was junk, a leftover from some long-forgotten repair. But to Fenwick, it was a component looking for a system. He pointed. "That. What are those pipes below us? On the outside of the shaft?" Kaelen glanced down, then back at the mirror. "Condensate return lines for the old heating system. Decommissioned. No pressure." A plan sparked, a perfect synthesis of their two disciplines. "But they are connected," Fenwick whispered, "to the active boiler system further down. If we could connect that tube between the drain valve on one line and the intake on another..." Kaelen finished the thought, a predatory gleam in their eye. "...we could create a small, unauthorized pressure loop. It would make a noise. A high-pitched whistle. Then, when the pressure builds, a seal will blow. A jet of hot steam, directed away from us, right into the guard's territory. He'll think it's a critical failure." The plan was beautiful in its elegance: using the foundry's own power system to create a perfectly sorted, localized pocket of chaos.

The execution was a terrifying ballet of silent cooperation. Kaelen, with the wiry strength of a creature born to climb, leaned precariously out of the service hatch, their feet braced by Fenwick. The heat from the foundry floor below was a physical force, trying to push them back. With one of Kaelen's probes, they managed to hook the copper tube and draw it into the shaft. The next part was harder. Fenwick held the mirror, providing Kaelen with a clear view of the two valves below, while Kaelen, using their long, thin arms, reached down. The noise of the Anvil was their shield, masking the faint scraping sounds as Kaelen worked the tube into place, their fingers twisting the small valve wheels. For a tense minute, nothing happened. Then came a low hum, which quickly rose in pitch to a piercing, high-frequency whistle that cut through even the roar of the hammer. The lounging guard's head snapped up. He looked around, annoyed. Just as he was about to dismiss it, a rusted seam on the pipe below burst with a deafening *WHOOSH*, vomiting a dense cloud of superheated steam and scalding water onto the floor a dozen feet from his position. He swore a guttural curse, jumping to his feet, and stomped off towards the hissing, billowing cloud, brandishing his rebar as if he could threaten the pipe into fixing itself. Their window was open.

"Now," Kaelen breathed, and they were moving. They slipped out of the shaft and onto the service platform, the transition from relative cool to the full, blistering heat of the foundry a shocking, physical blow. The maintenance ladder was hot enough to be painful, even through the thin soles of their footwear. Fenwick followed Kaelen down, his eyes wide, refusing to look at the sheer drop below. The rhythmic *CLANG* of the Anvil was no longer just a sound; it was a concussion that travelled up the ladder, through his body, and into his skull. The air tasted of hot, wet metal. Down on the floor, surrounded by monolithic machinery, the scale of the operation was even more monstrous. The pulsing light revealed details he had missed from above: goblins with oil-blackened faces hauling chains, others sharpening tools on grinding wheels that threw off showers of angry sparks. It was a city of ruinous labor.

They reached the bottom and darted into the deep shadows behind the dormant boiler Kaelen had identified. They were in the belly of the beast. Ahead, a narrow iron gantry, little more than a catwalk, snaked its way between colossal pipes and over the smouldering mountain of crushed scrap. It was their only path. Kaelen went first, moving with a low, fluid grace. Fenwick followed, his heart a frantic drum against his ribs. He forced himself not to look down at the sheer drop into the glowing, hissing slag pit below, focusing instead on the rust-pitted walkway in front of him. The heat rising from the scrap heap was intense, shimmering in the air, carrying with it the smell of a hundred murdered objects crying out at once. From this vantage point, he had a clear view of the finishing stations. He saw a Corruptor take a perfectly good clock, a beautiful thing of polished wood and brass, and methodically smash its face with a hammer before tossing it onto a pile destined for the Anvil. The casual, thoughtless cruelty of the act was a dagger in Fenwick's soul.

They were halfway across when it happened. A Corruptor on the floor below, hauling a heavy crate of newly-corroded bearings, stumbled, dropping his load with a resounding crash. The noise was different enough from the foundry's rhythm that several goblins, including a hulking overseer with a braided metal whip at his belt, turned to look. Their gazes swept the floor, then drifted upwards, towards the shadowy latticework of pipes and gantries. Fenwick and Kaelen froze instantly, pressing themselves flat against a large, cylindrical duct that ran alongside their catwalk. Fenwick held his breath until his lungs burned. The overseer’s eyes, small and cruel in his broad face, seemed to linger on their section of the gantry for an eternity. Fenwick could see the Unmaker's spiral crudely tattooed on the goblin's thick neck. The overseer grunted, barked an order at the clumsy goblin on the floor, and turned away. The moment passed. Fenwick let out his breath in a silent, shuddering rush. The world was still heat and noise and terror, but for now, they remained unseen, two small specks of order hidden in the vast, chaotic machine.

The overseer’s gaze passed over them, a brief, contemptuous flicker that dismissed the upper shadows as irrelevant, and then returned to the clumsy worker below. The moment of peril, stretched taut as a breaking wire, finally snapped. Fenwick let out a breath he didn't realize he had been holding for the better part of a minute, the air rushing from his lungs in a silent, shuddering gasp. Kaelen gave a single, sharp nod, and they were moving again, their forms melting from the solid shadow of the duct back into the flickering gloom of the catwalk. The rest of the journey across the gantry was a waking nightmare, each footstep a calculated risk on the narrow, vibrating walkway. Below them, the mountain of crushed potential grew with every catastrophic blow of the Anvil, a monument to a world being murdered one perfectly good object at a time.

As they drew closer to the far side, Fenwick risked another glance with his improvised periscope. He focused on a section of the workshop he hadn't seen clearly before, a packing and shipping area. Here, the Corruptors’ work achieved its final, insidious form. He watched as goblins packed the acid-dipped bearings and pre-stripped screws into small wooden crates. But they weren't just throwing them in a box. They were carefully wrapping some of the items in oilcloth, arranging them with a grotesque parody of a Sorter's care. Another goblin was stencilling the outsides of the crates, not with the Unmaker’s spiral, but with the legitimate trade-sigils of well-known goblin salvage guilds from distant cities. It was a revelation of breathtaking evil. They weren't just creating chaos; they were disguising it as order. They were poisoning the very arteries of goblin commerce, turning the trust-based system of salvage and trade into a delivery mechanism for their plague of dysfunction. The Miasma from the Glimmer-Moth’s scroll was not a creeping fog; it was a packaged good, boxed, labeled, and shipped with malicious intent.

They finally reached the end of the gantry, stepping onto a small, rickety wooden platform that groaned under their combined weight. Here, away from the direct blast of heat from the slag pit, the air was marginally cooler, though no less thick with fumes. Before them rose a short, steep flight of stairs leading to the foreman's office, a grim-looking brick box bolted to the cavern wall. The door was a slab of riveted iron, seemingly salvaged from a ship's hull, and set into its center was a lock that made Fenwick's blood run cold. It was not a simple pin-tumbler or a warded lock. It was a complex, goblin-made puzzle box of interlocking brass plates and gears, its faceplate adorned with a single, perfectly machined inward-coiling spiral that served as the keyhole. It was a declaration, a challenge, a piece of functional art dedicated to the principle of exclusion and failure.

Kaelen approached the door, their face a mask of intense, professional concentration. From their kit, they produced not a simple set of picks, but a delicate roll of fine wires, polished steel probes, and a small, articulated mirror on a thin rod. This was their domain. For several minutes, the only sound was the distant, rhythmic thunder of the Anvil and the faint, metallic scrape of Kaelen's tools. They probed the spiral keyhole, listened with their ear pressed to the cold iron, and peered inside with the tiny mirror. Finally, they pulled back, their expression grim. "It's a Chaos Lock," they whispered, their voice tight with a mixture of professional disgust and grudging respect. "The tumblers are designed to catch and shear. The third pin is hardened steel, but the fourth is soft brass. If you apply too much pressure, it will deform and jam the core permanently. It's a lock designed to Unsort the key that tries to open it."

Fenwick stared at the malevolent little machine, a perfect microcosm of the entire foundry. It was a system designed to punish any attempt to engage with it, a trap disguised as a mechanism. While Kaelen contemplated the impossible mechanics, Fenwick’s Sorter’s eye roamed over the door as a whole, cataloguing it not as a lock but as an assembly of parts. The iron plate was solid, the frame was bolted deep into the brickwork, but the hinges… the hinges were different. They were massive, brutal things, but the pins holding the two halves of each hinge together were strangely new. They were shiny, almost too shiny, and lacked the honest patina of age or the greasy coating of proper maintenance. He recognized the look. It was the false sheen of metal that had been chemically treated, artificially aged. They were Seeds of Decay, built into the Corruptors' own security. They were so consumed by their philosophy that they had built a fatal flaw into their own fortress, a slow-acting poison that would eventually bring their own door crashing down. They just never expected "eventually" to be tonight. "Kaelen," Fenwick whispered, pointing. "Forget the lock. The answer isn't in the complexity. It's in the corruption. Unmake the hinges."

Kaelen’s eyes, which had been minutely focused on the complex guts of the Chaos Lock, shifted to the brutish, oversized hinges. For a moment, their expression remained one of intense, analytical concentration. Then, a slow change occurred. The professional frustration eased, replaced by a dawning, incredulous awe. They looked from the hinges back to Fenwick, and a short, sharp huff of air escaped their lips—a sound that was half laugh, half gasp. The sheer, sublime irony of it was a thing of terrible beauty. The Corruptors, in their fanatical devotion to the principle of failure, had built the seeds of their own undoing into the very door of their sanctuary. It was a blind spot born of absolute faith in their own twisted creed.

“Of course,” Kaelen breathed, their voice a whisper of pure, unadulterated revelation. They ran a finger lightly over the surface of their own map on the sheet metal, as if recalibrating their entire understanding of the enemy. “We think of them as soldiers of chaos, but they are dogmatists. Their doctrine is so absolute they cannot conceive of it being used against them.” A fierce, predatory grin, the first genuine smile Fenwick had seen on their face, stretched across Kaelen’s grimy features. "You don't see a lock, Fenwick Mossbottom. You see an assembly of components, each with its own story, its own integrity… or lack thereof. They fortified their door, but you audited its parts list." In that moment, the division between their two disciplines dissolved. Fenwick the curator and Kaelen the analyst had become a single, formidable entity.

Tapping one of the gleaming hinge pins with the tip of a metal probe, Kaelen’s voice dropped into a clinical, explanatory tone. "I've seen this alloy before. It’s one of their more elegant creations. We call it 'Brittle-Blight.' It maintains its tensile strength under normal conditions, but it has an engineered catalytic flaw. It undergoes rapid structural decomposition when exposed to a specific polychlorinated biphenyl compound—a common, highly corrosive byproduct of the old transformer coolants. It's designed to make salvaged machinery fail catastrophically weeks or months after being put back into service.” Kaelen pointed a thin, trembling finger towards the floor of the foundry, where dark, iridescent slicks pooled near the bases of several ancient, humming power conduits. "They're so proud of their own filth they don't even bother cleaning it up. That's not just oil down there. That's the key. That’s the acid that un-makes their own hinges."

The new problem presented itself with terrifying clarity: they needed to fetch a sample of that corrosive sludge from the main foundry floor, a space teeming with hostile Corruptors, and bring it back up to the platform. It was a journey into the heart of the enemy stronghold to steal their poison. Kaelen began assessing their kit, looking for a vial or container, but Fenwick was already shrugging his burlap sack from his shoulder. From it, he produced the patched, rubbery form of his waterskin. It was more than half full of the precious, clean water they had brought from Kaelen's burrow. Without a word, he uncapped it and, with a grimace of profound regret, poured the life-giving liquid out onto the dusty platform, where it was instantly swallowed by the grime. He was sacrificing their certainty of survival for a chance at victory. He held up the now-empty vessel. "It has a watertight seal," he stated simply.

The operation was one of silent, desperate fishing. Kaelen unspooled their coil of high-tensile wire, tying one end securely around the neck of Fenwick's waterskin. Fenwick, meanwhile, acted as the lookout, using his locket-periscope to monitor the patrol patterns on the floor below, calling out quiet warnings when a Corruptor’s path strayed too close. Under the cover of the Anvil’s next deafening blow, Kaelen lowered the waterskin down into the shadows, swinging it like a pendulum towards a particularly large, dark puddle shimmering with chemical rainbows. The skin dipped into the viscous liquid with a soft splash that was utterly lost in the surrounding din. Kaelen hauled it back up, hand over hand, their muscles straining. The waterskin, now coated in a foul, greasy film, felt heavier, its contents sloshing with a malevolent thickness. They had their catalyst.

With the delicate care of a bomb disposal expert, Kaelen unscrewed the cap and, using one of their probes as a dropper, began to apply the toxic liquid to the hinge pins. The effect was both immediate and horrifying. The moment the first drop of the oily sludge touched the gleaming pin, a faint, sizzling sound, like water on a hot skillet, hissed in the brief silence between hammer blows. A thin wisp of acrid, green-tinged smoke curled into the air. The mirror-sheen of the Brittle-Blight alloy instantly clouded, and a spiderweb of hairline, black cracks spread across its surface. They worked quickly, anointing all four pin-heads with the corrosive fluid, their hearts hammering in time with the Un-maker’s Anvil. Then, there was nothing to do but wait, exposed and vulnerable on their tiny platform, hoping the engineered failure would be swift.

It was. With a sudden, sharp crack that was higher and more piercing than any sound in the foundry, the head of the top hinge pin shattered, spraying fragments of black, crystalline metal. The massive iron door, weighing hundreds of pounds, tore free from the top of its frame with a shriek of tortured steel and swung downwards, hanging for a single, precarious second from the bottom hinge. A heartbeat later, with a final, groaning scream of protest, the lower hinge gave way entirely. The door did not swing open; it fell inwards, crashing onto the floor of the foreman's office with a cataclysmic BOOM that was utterly distinct from the foundry's rhythm. For the first time since they had arrived, the thunderous, rhythmic clang of the Anvil ceased. An unnatural silence descended upon the cavern, broken only by the hiss of steam and the confused shouts of the Corruptors. Every single head on the foundry floor snapped up, their malevolent eyes fixing on the dark, gaping doorway where a door had just been. Their alarm had been sounded. "Go!" Kaelen yelled, and they scrambled over the threshold into the sudden darkness of the office, the hunt already beginning behind them.

### Chapter 10

The silence that followed the crash was a physical thing, a vacuum that sucked the air from Fenwick’s lungs. It was a silence more terrifying than the cacophony it had replaced, a void defined by the sudden absence of the Anvil's monstrous heartbeat. For a single, suspended moment, the entire foundry held its breath. Then the void was shattered by a chorus of furious, guttural shouts from the cavern floor, the sound of a kicked hornet’s nest. Heavy, running footsteps echoed from below, and the sharp, metallic clang of weapons being readied. The hunt had begun.

Fenwick and Kaelen scrambled through the gaping doorway into the foreman's office, the sudden darkness of the interior a stark contrast to the lurid glow of the foundry. As their eyes adjusted, Fenwick saw that the room was not the chaotic sty he had expected. It was a place of chilling, perverse order. A large desk, constructed from layers of scrap metal compressed into a solid, multi-coloured block, dominated the center of the room. The walls were lined not with shelves of scavenged treasures, but with neat rows of metal trays, each containing a single, failed object. A gear with its teeth systematically ground down. A bolt with its threads intentionally crossed. A wire with its insulation meticulously stripped away in a spiral pattern. Each item was accompanied by a small, neatly lettered tag, a label describing its specific mode of engineered failure. It was a museum of malfunction, a library of decay.

“The manifests, the logbooks,” Kaelen hissed, their voice tight with urgency as they began yanking open the drawers of a tall metal filing cabinet. The screech of the drawers was obscenely loud in the tense quiet. Fenwick, his mind reeling from the sight of this sanctuary of anti-purpose, forced himself into action. He lunged for the main desk, his hands sweeping across its surface. He found blueprints, not for buildings or machines, but for brokenness—schematics detailing the most efficient way to compromise a load-bearing joint, diagrams illustrating the precise application of corrosive agents. The sound from outside grew louder, closer. The heavy, rhythmic thud of hobnailed boots was on the wooden stairs now, a determined, ascending beat of doom. They had seconds.

There, sitting in the center of the desk as if it were a holy text, was a massive ledger. It was bound in a material that looked like vulcanized rubber, thick and black, and the inward-coiling spiral of the Unmaker was embossed on its cover, not with ink or paint, but branded deep into the material. It was cold and heavy in Fenwick’s hands. He flipped it open. The pages were not paper, but thin, flexible sheets of processed plastic, and the script that covered them was a thing of terrible, undeniable beauty. It was the elegant, precise, and perfectly legible hand of a master scribe, a stark contrast to the foulness of its content.

Fenwick’s eyes scanned the page, his Sorter’s mind rapidly cataloguing the information. He saw lists of chemical formulas, including one for an alloy labeled ‘Brittle-Blight.’ He saw production quotas for ‘Self-Stripping Screws, Grade 5.’ He saw shipping manifests, lists of guild-marked crates filled with Seeds of Decay being sent to nodes all across the continent, their destinations chillingly familiar: ‘Halifax Salvage Node, Attn: Dockmaster.’ ‘Montréal Metro-Warren, Sector Gamma.’ The Miasma was not just spreading; it was being delivered by registered post. The scale of the conspiracy was staggering, a web of corruption that stretched far beyond this single foundry. Then, at the bottom of a page detailing a new formula for a light-sensitive adhesive designed to fail under stress, he saw a signature. It was an entry signed not with a crude mark, but with a flourish of arcane, scholarly script: *Griswold, Chief Ontologist.*

The name struck Fenwick with the force of a physical blow, knocking the wind from him. Griswold the Artificer. It was a name from the fish-skin scrolls, a name spoken with the same reverence as the founders of the High Council. Griswold had not just been a Sorter; he had been a legendary philosopher of the craft, one of the original theorists of the Covenant of Reclamation. His essays on the ‘Spirit of the Object’ and the ‘Ethics of Repurposing’ were foundational texts, required reading for any goblin aspiring to the title of Master Sorter. Fenwick had practically memorized them. The architect of their faith was the high priest of this new, nihilistic heresy. The betrayal was so profound, so absolute, it felt like the ground had fallen away beneath him, leaving him dangling over an abyss of pure contradiction.

“Fenwick!” Kaelen’s sharp voice snapped him out of his horrified trance. The footsteps had reached the top of the stairs. A hulking silhouette, armed with a notched iron club, filled the broken doorway, followed immediately by another. They were trapped. Kaelen, their back to the wall, scanned the office with frantic, desperate eyes. Their gaze landed on a row of large clay jars on a high shelf, each meticulously labeled. They grabbed a heavy wrench from the desk, and with a surprisingly powerful throw, hurled it at the shelf. The wrench struck a jar labeled ‘Rapid Oxidizer Compound #7 (Air-sensitive)’, shattering it. A cloud of fine, grey powder billowed into the room.

The two Corruptors at the door charged forward, but as they hit the cloud of dust, a bizarre and horrifying transformation occurred. The fine powder, reacting instantly with the moisture in the air, caused a chain reaction of flash-rusting. Their iron clubs, their scavenged metal armor, even the buckles on their belts, bloomed with a thick, orange crust of corrosion in a matter of seconds. The goblins cried out in shock and pain as their own gear seized, their joints freezing, their weapons crumbling to orange dust in their hands. They were statues of rust, immobilized by their own master’s chemical ingenuity.

The momentary victory was a gasp of air before drowning. More shouts erupted from the stairs as other Corruptors pushed past their frozen comrades. "The chute!" Kaelen yelled, kicking aside a small, circular metal plate in the floor that Fenwick had mistaken for a drain cover. It revealed a dark, square hole, a smooth-sided shaft that plunged straight down into blackness. "Ore sample chute! It goes down to the old assay office!" Clutching the Unmaker's ledger to his chest as if it were the most precious object in the world, Fenwick scrambled for the opening. He took one last look back at the office, a monument to a philosophy he now understood was wielded by a fallen hero. The doorway was crowded with the snarling, furious faces of more Corruptors, their eyes burning with hatred in the fiery glow of the foundry. With no other choice, he swung his legs into the hole and let go, plunging into the cold, claustrophobic darkness. Kaelen followed a second behind him, pulling the cover partially back into place just as a thrown rebar spear sparked against the rim. They fell together, the thunder of the awakened Un-foundry roaring above them like a promise of vengeance.

The fall was a blind, scraping rush through absolute darkness. The chute was a smooth, cold throat of riveted iron, and they slid down it with terrifying speed, tumbling over each other in a disoriented tangle of limbs. Fenwick clutched the heavy, rubber-bound ledger to his chest with a death grip, its hard edges digging into his ribs with every bump and turn. It was the single most important object in the world, a concentrate of pure, weaponized chaos, and he would sooner part with his own arm than lose it to the dark. The roaring fury of the foundry above receded with distance, replaced by the deafening shriek of their own passage against the metal. He had a brief, disconnected sensation of Kaelen’s hand grabbing his sack to keep them from separating, a small, desperate act of order in their shared, vertiginous plunge.

The descent ended not with a gradual slowdown, but with a brutal, jarring impact. They were spat out of the chute’s mouth and tumbled onto a floor cushioned by a thick, soft layer of fine, dark grey powder. The abrupt landing knocked the wind out of Fenwick, and he lay there for a moment, gasping in the sudden, profound silence. The powder, which coated his clothes and filled his nostrils with a dry, mineral scent, billowed around them in a thick cloud. A single, weak shaft of light from a high, grime-caked window cut through the gloom, illuminating the swirling dust motes like a galaxy of tiny, dead stars. As the dust settled, Fenwick pushed himself up, his entire body aching, the weight of the ledger a familiar anchor in the disorientation.

They were in a place of quiet, meticulous ghosts. This was the assay office, a laboratory for testing the purity of ore, and it was a perfect inverse of the foundry above. Delicate brass scales, their pans empty but perfectly balanced, sat on long wooden benches. Racks of tiny, numbered ceramic crucibles stood in neat rows, waiting for samples that would never come. Faded, hand-drawn charts depicting geological strata and mineral yields were pinned to the walls, their edges curling with age. It was a chapel dedicated to the Sorter’s most fundamental act: discerning the nature of a thing, understanding its value, and classifying it. The air was still and reverent, holding the memory of a quieter, more analytical form of creation. The contrast with the violent anti-creation they had just fled was so stark it made Fenwick’s head spin.

“We’re clear. For now.” Kaelen’s voice was a low, rough whisper that seemed to treat the silence with respect. They were already on their feet, checking their meager equipment, their gaze sweeping the room for exits and threats. But Fenwick did not move. He sat in the soft grey dust, the ledger heavy in his lap. He ran his hand over the embossed, inward-coiling spiral, the symbol of a betrayal so deep it felt personal. He opened the book again, his fingers tracing the elegant, looping script on the plastic pages, a calligraphy he knew as well as his own name. “Griswold,” he breathed, the name a strange and bitter taste in his mouth. Kaelen paused, turning to look at him. “You know that name.”

“Every Sorter knows that name,” Fenwick said, his voice hollow. He felt a tremor begin in his hands, a deep-seated shudder of a faith collapsing. “Griswold the Artificer wasn’t just a Sorter. He was one of the First Thinkers. He wrote the founding texts of the Covenant of Reclamation. *The Metaphysics of Rust, The Latent Spirit of the Discarded Object*. His work… it is our scripture. It is the foundation of everything we believe. The idea that every object has a soul, that our sacred duty is to honor that soul through categorization and reuse… it all came from him.” He looked up at Kaelen, his luminous eyes wide with a horrified, pleading confusion. “The goblin who taught us to find order in chaos is the one leading this… this Great Unsorting. How? Why? It’s like finding out the sun has decided to become a black hole. It invalidates everything.”

Kaelen listened, their expression unreadable. They walked over and knelt beside Fenwick, but their attention was not on Fenwick’s existential crisis. It was on the ledger. “A fallen priest is still a source of information,” they said, their tone not unkind, but ruthlessly practical. “His past philosophy is irrelevant. His current logistics are our only concern. Does the book tell us where his patrols are? Does it show the foundry’s shift changes? Does it list the other nests?” They tapped the plastic page with a grimy finger. “Your scripture has become our timetable. Your fallen hero has given us the weapon we need to tear his new church down. We must use it.” The cold, clear logic cut through the fog of Fenwick’s despair, offering not comfort, but a direction.

He handed the heavy ledger to Kaelen, a transfer of responsibility. Kaelen’s eyes, accustomed to reading the complex language of schematics, devoured the information. They flipped through the pages, their lips moving silently, their mind cross-referencing the neatly written columns of data with their own encyclopedic knowledge of the under-city. Fenwick watched, his own mind still struggling to reconcile the beautiful script with the ugly truth it described. He felt like he was poring over a sacred text that had been possessed by a demon, its elegant verses twisted into curses. Just as Kaelen’s finger stopped on a particular page, a faint sound from above made them both freeze. It was the screech of the chute cover being pried open, followed by the muffled, guttural shouts of Corruptors echoing down the shaft. They had found their escape route. The search was coming down to their level.

“Here,” Kaelen hissed, their voice sharp and urgent. “A schedule for waste slurry disposal. They flush the system every twelve hours. According to this, the main western drainage conduit was flushed an hour ago. It will be empty, but the Corruptors will avoid it, assuming it's full of toxic sludge.” They pointed to a dark, low-arched opening in the far wall of the assay office, an opening Fenwick had assumed was a collapsed alcove. “That’s an access tunnel. It will take us there. It’s our only way out of the Ironworks sector before they seal it completely.” The sounds from the chute were louder now, the scrape of goblin claws on metal. They had moments.

Kaelen slammed the ledger shut and shoved it deep into Fenwick’s burlap sack, the responsibility for the artifact returned to its discoverer. “Move. Now.” They darted towards the low opening, Fenwick scrambling behind them, his bruised shoulder screaming in protest. As he ducked into the narrow, brick-lined passage, he cast one last look back at the assay office, the quiet room of scales and crucibles about to be overrun by the servants of the very goblin who had once championed such places. A chilling thought solidified in his mind, as hard and cold as the ledger now pressed against his back. Griswold, the master theorist, would not be satisfied with merely breaking the world. He would seek to convert it. The Un-foundry wasn't just a factory; it was a recruitment center, a place to prove that Unsorting was the more powerful, more fundamental truth of the universe. They were not just fighting an army of thugs. They were fighting the first apostles of a new, dark faith, and they carried its holy book. The thought was still echoing in his mind as they plunged into the tunnel, the sounds of the hunt nipping at their heels.
